subject: Re: [junit] @AfterClass is poorly defined
msgSnippet: ... I agree. No reason those fields have to be instance-level. If multiple instances of tests plan to share them, then, by definition, they ought to be
messageBody:
On Thu, Mar 5, 2009 at 10:14 AM, Cenk Ã‡ivici <cenk.civici@...> wrote:
> It makes sense to use BeforeClass and AfterClass in integration tests
> when you need to initialize expensive resources such the spring
> context, hibernate sessionfactory, configuration etc. In BeforeClass
> create the environment needed for such integration tests to run and
> do your cleanup in AfterClass.

I agree. No reason those fields have to be instance-level. If multiple
instances of tests plan to share them, then, by definition, they ought
to be class-level.
